importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the game, October 18, 2025, marks the culmination of the National League Championship Series, with Shohei Ohtani's historic performance leading the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, securing their spot in the World Series.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 2025 postseason is significant as it features Shohei Ohtani's unprecedented two-way performance, which has become a defining moment in modern baseball history and may influence how the sport evaluates player excellence and performance in high-stakes environments.

keyTakeAways: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in Game 4 of the 2025 National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout ball into the seventh inning.
The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers in the NLCS, marking the first time a team has swept an NLCS since Washington in 2019 and only the fifth such sweep in postseason history.

Ohtani's performance is widely regarded as one of the greatest individual postseason performances ever, leading to his selection as the NLCS MVP and cementing his legacy as a dominant force in baseball.
The Dodgers became the first team to win back-to-back pennants since Philadelphia in 2009, and they are now set to face the Seattle Mariners in the World Series after a 9-1 playoff run.

The Milwaukee Brewers, who had a franchise-record 97 wins during the regular season, were eliminated for the third time in their recent playoff run, highlighting the dominance of the Dodgers' pitching and Ohtani's all-around impact.
The game is remembered as 'the Shohei Ohtani game,' a pivotal moment in modern baseball history due to its unprecedented scale and impact on the postseason narrative.

namedEntities.name: Shohei Ohtani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Japanese-American professional baseball player and two-way superstar (pitcher and hitter)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ohtani is the central figure of the article, performing an unprecedented two-way performance by hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters in a single game, which led to the Dodgers' victory and earned him NLCS MVP honors.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Los Angeles, competing in the National League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers won the National League Championship Series by sweeping the Milwaukee Brewers, advancing to the World Series for the 23rd time in franchise history and becoming the first team to win back-to-back pennants since 2009.

namedEntities.name: Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Major League Baseball team based in Milwaukee, competing in the National League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Brewers were swept by the Dodgers in the NLCS, marking their third elimination in their recent playoff run and ending their wait for a World Series appearance since 1982.

namedEntities.name: Dave Roberts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Roberts praised Ohtani's performance as one of the greatest postseason outings in history, highlighting the significance of the game within the team's postseason strategy and legacy.

namedEntities.name: Freddie Freeman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodgers player and previous World Series MVP
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Freeman praised Ohtani's performance as 'absolutely incredible' and emphasized the emotional and historic impact of such a dominant display on the biggest stage.

namedEntities.name: Jose Quintana
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Starting pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Quintana was the pitcher Ohtani faced in the top of the first inning, where Ohtani hit a leadoff home run off him, marking a historic moment in MLB history as the first leadoff homer by a pitcher.

namedEntities.name: Roki Sasaki
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodgers relief pitcher and rookie closer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sasaki pitched the ninth inning in the final game of the NLCS, contributing to the Dodgers' victory and maintaining a strong bullpen performance.

namedEntities.name: Mookie Betts
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dodgers player and key contributor in the offensive lineup
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Betts and Will Smith scored off Ohtani’s first homer, contributing to the early scoring in the game and helping build momentum for the Dodgers.

namedEntities.name: Blake Perkins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Perkins acknowledged the team’s struggles against the Dodgers’ pitching and noted that key batters failed to produce, emphasizing the impact of Ohtani’s performance.

namedEntities.name: Pat Murphy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Murphy acknowledged Ohtani’s performance as 'iconic' and one of the greatest individual performances in postseason history, even though his team lost the series.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: American League team competing in the ALCS against the Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the eventual World Series opponent of the Dodgers after winning a 3-2 lead in the ALCS, creating a matchup scenario that will be central to the 2025 World Series.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Canadian team in the American League competing in the ALCS
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays were defeated by the Mariners in the ALCS, setting up a World Series matchup between the Dodgers and Mariners, which will be broadcast globally.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Shohei Ohtani delivered a historic two-way performance in Game 4 of the 2025 National League Championship Series, hitting three home runs and striking out 10 batters while pitching shutout ball into the seventh inning. The Los Angeles Dodgers swept the Milwaukee Brewers, marking the first time a team has swept an NLCS since Washington in 2019 and only the fifth such sweep in postseason history. Ohtani's performance is hailed as one of the greatest individual postseason outings in baseball history, earning him NLCS MVP honors. The Dodgers, now back in the World Series for the fifth time in nine seasons, aim to become the first team to win back-to-back pennants since Philadelphia in 2009. The Milwaukee Brewers, despite a regular-season record of 97 wins, were eliminated for the third time in their recent playoff run, and their postseason struggles were highlighted by their inability to hit against the Dodgers' dominant starting rotation. The game is remembered as 'the Shohei Ohtani game,' a defining moment in modern baseball history due to its unprecedented scale and impact on the postseason narrative.
title: Shohei Ohtani hits 3 homers and strikes out 10 in Dodgers' clinching 5-1 NLCS win over Brewers
